title-group.article-title: Notions of Identity, Society, and Rhetoric in a Speech Code of Science Among Scientists and Engineers Working in Nanotechnology

author-notes.corresp: Deborah R. Bassett, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, University of Washington School of Medicine, Harborview Medical Center, Box 359911, 325 9th Avenue, Seattle, WA 98104 Email: dbassett@uw.edu

fn.p: Deborah R. Bassett is a senior fellow and acting instructor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences in the School of Medicine, University of Washington. Her research interests include ethnography of communication, health communication, science and technology studies, and cultural communication.

abstract.p: This ethnography of communication was concerned with discovering a speech code in the discourse about values in science used by scientists and engineers working in nanoscale science and engineering. It was supported and guided by the theoretical framework of speech codes theory. Materials analyzed included 4 years of fieldwork at a U.S. research university and nanotechnology center and 20 in-depth interviews conducted with scientists and engineers working in nanotechnology. Data sets were constructed and analyzed to identify a distinctive speech code about science and social and ethical implications of nanotechnology that contains beliefs among its users about identity, society, and rhetoric.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In 1959, Richard Feynman delivered a speech titled “There’s Plenty of Room at the Bottom” to the American Physical Society in which he proposed developing science and technology that would enable manipulation of matter at molecular and atomic levels. Although this speech (Feynman, 1960) can be seen as the origin of nanoscale science and engineering (NSE), or nanoscience and nanotechnologies, as a formal proposal, these labels only began to emerge some 25 years later with the publication of K. Eric Drexler’s (1986) book Engines of Creation in which he introduced the term nanotechnology.

Bennett and Sarewitz (2006) traced the development of the nano phenomenon, showing how U.S. federal funding for NSE shot up dramatically from $6 million in 1991 to $961 million by 2004 and “nano” began showing up in exponentially increasing numbers in titles of journal articles, journal titles, and grant proposals. For example, the number of articles listed in the Science Citation Index containing the word nano in their titles increased from several hundred in the late 1980s to more than 23,000 in 2003 and more than 150,000 in 2009.

Around the same time that the term nano was appearing with increasing frequency in journals and grant proposals, K. Eric Drexler, an engineer from MIT, published Engines of Creation (1986), the earliest detailed account of how nanotechnologies might develop. And although Drexler’s account was overwhelmingly optimistic, his description of the possible risk of self-assembling nanobots going amuck and attacking the biosphere (a scenario that is referred to as “the grey goo” problem) created concerns about the development of self-assembling molecules, or molecular manufacturing.

These concerns led to consumer and environmental groups such as the ETC Group calling for a moratorium on research that would lead to molecular manufacturing (ETC Group, 2003). However, it was not until 2000 when Wired magazine ran a cover story by then CEO of Sun Microsystems Bill Joy (2000) titled “Why the Future Doesn’t Need Us” about the impact of nanotechnologies that it reached a level of noise that began to receive media, public, and scholarly attention.

Although many in the mainstream scientific community reject Drexler’s vision, as well as Joy’s concerns, molecular manufacturing is referred to as “the holy grail” of NSE research and development (McKibben, 2003, p. 80; and my own personal communication with NSE scientists and engineers), and the same revolutionary narrative that is applied to NSE by Drexler and others is deployed by the mainstream scientific community (Sparrow, 2007). Within the past few years, “nanotechnology” has become a trendy buzzword among science and technology circles, as well as in popular media, and was introduced into the mass consumer lexicon with the unveiling of the “nano” iPod by Apple in 2005. In the meantime, true nano-enhanced products have quietly been appearing in the consumer market, particularly in the personal care products market such as transparent sunscreens with high sun protection factors, among more than 1,000 currently available consumer products that use nanoscale materials (The Project on Emerging Nanotechnologies, 2011). Nanotech research firms estimate that production of nanotech products and services in industries such as information technology, medical devices, energy, and aircraft and auto manufacturing will reach $2.6 trillion by 2015 (Uldrich, 2007).

Although there is significant disagreement about the definition of “nanotechnology” (with some scientists arguing that the label is simply a new construct for old processes), I will use the broad definition used by the participants in this study, that is, that nanotechnology refers to both the tools and the ability to manipulate matter at the nanoscale (1 billionth of a meter). Throughout this text I use the following terms synonymously: nano, nanotech, nanotechnology, nanotechnologies, and NSE. In doing so, I followed the lead of the participants in my study and the literature I encountered. Although I agree with Schummer’s (2007) point that nanotechnology is an inaccurate term in the singular since, there are presently several hundred different technologies in existence that can be considered nanotechnologies, I found that the singular term was used most frequently by participants in my study and have thus opted to use it here.

Schummer (2007) identified three different approaches to defining nanotechnologies, with the caveat that “all are conspicuously vague” (p. 293). The first approach Schummer presents is that of a “nominal definition,” which “provides necessary and sufficient conditions that a technology must meet to be called a nanotechnology.” Schummer notes that “[t]ypical definitions” of nanotechnology refer to a size range of 1 to 100 nanometers but suggests that this definition is problematic as it “covers all the classical natural science and engineering disciplines that investigate and manipulate material objects” (p. 293). Among scientists and engineers, popular definitions of nanoscience and nanotechnology tend to be nominal definitions (see, e.g., Ratner & Ratner, 2003). This may be precisely because the definition is vague, and thus, nonthreatening. Indeed, Ratner and Ratner (2003) describe their own definition (a nominal definition) as “[not] a very sexy or fulfilling definition” (p. 7).

Schummer also identified a “teleological definition,” which “defines nanotechnology by its future goals.” He criticized this definition, saying it is “impracticable to identify current research as belonging to nanotechnology by the visions that researchers publicly propagate” (Schummer, 2007, p. 293). However, teleological definitions do carry the excitement that nominal definitions lack and are commonly used among proponents of nanotechnology, such as Mihail Roco, one of the key figures who developed the National Nanotechnology Initiative (NNI) in the United States.

The third definitional approach Schummer identified is that of “real definition,” which “refers to a list of specific research topics.” Schummer lists many examples of nanotechnology including microelectronical mechanical systems, nanoparticle research, and targeted drug delivery. Interestingly, NNI, the U.S. federal program that oversees federal funding for nanotechnology and development, uses all three of the above definitions to explain nanotechnology on its website (http://www.nano.gov/nanotech-101/nanotechnology-facts).

sec.title: Social and Ethical Issues (SEI) Raised by NSE
sec.p: Regardless of which of the above definitions is used, a key aspect of nanotechnology inherent in all three of the definitions Schummer identifies is that it enables, potentially, the discovery of new phenomena and applications such as those that mimic the powerful capabilities of nature (Alivisatos, Roco, & Williams, 1999). Once mastered, the potential that such ability appears to hold is seemingly all-pervasive in improving the quality of life, with developing applications in the manufacturing of improved materials for aircraft and automobiles, faster and smaller communications devices and electronics, more efficient environmental innovations, improved security devices, and targeted drug delivery systems (Alivisatos et al., 1999; Jelinski, 1999). Perhaps one of the most exciting potential applications of nanoscience is the treatment (and even elimination) of disease through nanomedical applications. Some proponents of the technologies even go so far as to predict human immortality made possible by the convergence of genetics, nanotechnologies, and robotics (see Kurzweil, 2005). Some scholars have expressed concern regarding potential military applications of these technologies (see, e.g., Altmann, 2004). Others have suggested that the social and ethical implications of these technologies be examined prior to these anticipated revolutionary developments (see, e.g., Macnaghten, Kearnes, & Wynne, 2005).

Although the U.S. Federal Government has prioritized research on NSE since the passage of the 21st Century Nanotechnology Research and Development Act in 2003 through funding large-scale projects such as the NNI, less than 0.4% of the federal funding of NSE research has been allocated to addressing the social and ethical implications of such research (Bennett & Sarewitz, 2006). Research centers dealing with SEI related to nanotech are active at universities around the United States, the United Kingdom, and the European Union. Some projects, such as the NNI and the NNIN, which are discussed below, are only tangentially concerned with addressing SEI, and the rationale for doing so appears to be in the service of facilitating NSE development rather than raising substantive social and ethical questions about the technologies. The remaining projects reviewed below are explicitly concerned with studying the broad social and ethical implications of nanotechnologies.

The NNI was the first U.S. Federal initiative to address nanotechnology and nanoscience, established in 2000 to coordinate Federal nanotechnology research and development. The rationale for these efforts is to support the NNI “vision” of “a future in which the ability to understand and control matter at the nanoscale leads to a revolution in technology and industry that benefits society” (NNI, http://www.nano.gov/about-nni/what/vision-goals). Twenty-five federal agencies participate in the NNI, including the departments of Defense; Health and Human Services; Food and Drug Administration; Homeland Security; and the National Science Foundation.

The National Science Foundation currently funds two Centers for Nanotechnology in Society, one at Arizona State University and the other at the University of California, Santa Barbara. The explicit purpose of these centers is to study various aspects of nanotechnology in society. Additionally, a growing number of university research centers based in the United Kingdom and the European Union have focused on various efforts to engage the public in discussions about nanotechnology at the outset of research and development in order to promote ethical development of technologies (see, e.g., Stilgoe, 2007). These examples are just a few of the federally funded projects at universities and research centers around the world attempting to respond to calls for consideration of SEI in nanotech R&D.

Launched in 2004, the National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network (NNIN) is “an integrated partnership” of 13 nanotechnology user facilities “providing unparalleled opportunities for nanoscience and nanotechnology research” (http://www.nnin.org/index.html). The user facilities are located on university campuses across the United States. Eight of the 13 partnering institutions are involved in research on SEI related to nanotechnology, identified by the NNIN as the following: economic and political implications of potential technology; implications for science and education; medical, environmental, space exploration, and national security implications; and social, ethical, legal, and cultural implications (NNIN, 2008). I developed and implemented the study that follows over the 4 years (2005-2008) that I worked as a research assistant on the SEI team at one of the NNIN institutions.

sec.title: Theoretical Background
sec.p: Fetterman (2010) has stated that “no study, ethnographic or otherwise, can be conducted without an underlying theory or model” to guide one’s research (p. 5) and suggested that the theory should be selected on the basis of “appropriateness, ease of use, and explanatory power” (p. 7). With this in mind, I selected speech codes theory (SCT; Philipsen, 1997; Philipsen, Coutu, & Covarrubias, 2005) as the theoretical framework to support and guide this study. This approach originated out of a scholarly enterprise referred to as the ethnography of communication developed in the early 1960s by Dell Hymes (1927-present), an anthropologist and linguist. Hymes (1974) said that “[ethnography of communication] implies two characteristics that an adequate approach to language must have” (p. 3): ethnography, “investigat[ing] directly the use of language in contexts of situtations” (p. 3) and communication, “investigating [a community’s] communicative activities as a whole” (p. 4). Hymes (1962) had earlier described his approach to the study of language as answering “a question of what a foreigner must learn about a group’s verbal behavior in order to participate appropriately and effectively in its activities” (p. 16). In 1972, he recommended that comparative fieldwork studies of cultural ways of speaking be undertaken and called for “new types of discovery procedures and concepts designed to facilitate the empirical collection of data” (Hymes, 1972, p. 36). This call was answered by many scholars in multiple disciplines, first in the period of 1964-1972 with the work of prominent scholars such as anthropologists Ethel Albert (1972) and Keith Basso (1970), folklorist Richard Bauman (1970), and anthropologist and linguist Joel Sherzer (1973) (see Philipsen & Carbaugh, 1986, for a bibliography of approximately 210 published studies that responded to Hymes between 1964 and 1984; see Philipsen, 2010, for a recent overview of the approach). A second generation of scholars followed the 1964-1972 group, including Gerry Philipsen whose 1975 groundbreaking study of ways of speaking in a south Chicago neighborhood published in the Quarterly Journal of Speech is largely regarded as the introduction of the ethnography of communication as a scholarly enterprise into the communication discipline (Leeds-Hurwitz, 2005).

Responding to Hymes’s call for new resources to use when conducting ethnographies of communication, Philipsen introduced SCT in 1992, and the theory was formally explicated in 1997 (Philipsen) and revised in 2005 (Philipsen et al.). Philipsen (2002) described SCT in the following way:

disp-quote.p: A speech code, [speech codes theory] posits, implicates a distinctive way of answering the following questions: What is a person, and how is personhood efficaciously and properly enacted communicatively? What is an ideal state of sociation, and how do people efficaciously and properly link themselves into such states through communicative conduct? What are efficacious and proper means of communication, and what meanings are expressed in and through their situated use? (p. 56)

sec.p: SCT comprises six propositions which assert that in a given speech community, one or more speech codes implying a “distinctive psychology, sociology, and rhetoric” (Philipsen, 1997) can be identified through the communicative conduct of its users. Moreover, the theory asserts that an understanding of such speech codes used enables one to both predict and control some aspects of communicative conduct among those who use the code(s). Thus, SCT is concerned not only with describing the discourse in a given speech community but also with proposing a theoretic explanation specific to each speech community examined that accounts for the particular findings.

In addition to being part of the larger enterprise of the ethnography of communication as described above, this project is situated among the array of research from various disciplines addressing the social and ethical issues related to nanotechnologies in particular, and to science and technology in general. For example, Berube (2006) identified key arguments in the collective public discourse for and against nanotechnology, providing a thorough overview of the controversy around nanotechnology and identifying the primary actors in what Berube refers to as “the nanocommunity” (p. 43). It is my intention that the work presented here should provide additional depth and insight into the perspectives of one group of stakeholders in this conversation, that of the scientists and engineers working at the nanoscale.

Berne (2006) presented full texts of interviews with scientists and engineers about ethics in general and beliefs about science and technology, with particular emphasis on nanotechnologies. Using open coding and grounded theory, Berne identified 17 categories in the interviews, including the following categories that are relevant to my own analysis: personal aspirations, beliefs about science, perceptions about nanotechnology generally, conceptual blocks to ethics considerations, and pure science versus engineering or application (Berne, 2006, p. 327). Berne (2006) noted that “most [of the scientists and engineers she spoke to] are unable to make direct connections between ethics and what they do” (p. 116), a finding consistent with my own.

In addition to rhetorical analysis and the grounded theory approach, other approaches to studies of science and technology communication include framing theory and folk theories. Framing theory is used to explain how the presentation of a topic, including use of language, word choice, and metaphors, may influence how people think about the given topic, particularly in mass media news coverage. For example, Weaver, Lively, and Bimber (2009) used frame analysis to identify four issue frames for U.S. news media stories about nanoscale science and technology from 1999 to 2008 and found that early frames focused on progress and generic risk whereas frames after 2007 focused on regulation and conflict. Cobb (2005) used framing theory to assess public opinion about nanotechnology in a national survey and found that framing nanotechnology in a particular way in the survey appeared to influence public opinion about nanotechnology.

The concept of folk theories (Rip, 2006) is similar to SCT. Rip (2006) described folk theories as “evolve[ing] in ongoing practices,” “a form of expectations,” and “part of a repertoire” held by a group (p. 349). Similarly, SCT asserts that speech codes also evolve, that they exert a social force (not always followed, however), and that they function as a communicative resource (or repertoire) from which one may draw in order to communicate with others. Rip (2006) identified three clusters of folk theories related to nanotechnologies and suggested that the evolving nature of these theories provides opportunities for interactions with social scientists where folk theories can be addressed and debated.

While the above approaches are useful in understanding science communication and the discourse of scientists, Philipsen’s approach provides another set of theoretical resources that can be used not only to identify but also to negotiate the multiple, complex perspectives on social and ethical implications of emerging technologies held by diverse publics. Perspectives (folk theories, speech codes, rhetorical strategies, frames, etc.) on nanotechnology can be identified and analyzed using a variety of approaches as described above; however, by identifying the interconnected elements of a given speech code, SCT connects theory to practice by suggesting how these perspectives can be challenged, contested, and replaced through a discursive negotiation process in which parties are able to understand (if not always agree with) each other through the use of a shared speech code.

sec.title: Support for and Extension of SCT
sec.p: To date, a significant body of empirical evidence obtained within a diversity of communities, and encompassing many languages, cultures, and communicative practices, supports SCT. This literature includes Carbaugh’s (1988, 1993, 2005) studies of Blackfeet, Finnish, and American speech codes; Fong’s 1998 study of a Chinese speech code; Fitch’s 1991 study of Mexican speech codes; Katriel’s (1986, 2004) study of Israeli speech codes; Coutu’s 2000 study of American speech codes; Winchatz’s 2001 study of German speech codes; and Philipsen’s (1975, 1976, 1986, 1992, 2000) studies of American speech codes, to name a few of the many extant studies (Philipsen, 2002). These studies were used to help develop and provide empirical support for SCT and do so not just by offering a descriptive account of a given community’s culturally distinctive way of communicating but also by providing an understanding of the “culturally distinctive psychology, sociology, and rhetoric” (Philipsen et al., 2005, p. 61) embedded within these particular ways of communicating. For example, Winchatz (2001) found that the use of specific pronouns in personal address in Germany reflected the speakers’ beliefs about their relationships with others and had a powerful impact on things such as job satisfaction. Some of the published studies cited above have also extended SCT. Coutu (2000), for example, found evidence of more than one speech code in her study of discourse about Robert McNamara’s role in the Vietnam War. This led to the addition of a new proposition to SCT stating that multiple speech codes, rather than one, will be deployed in any given speech community.

SCT thus offers a theoretical resource that can be used to discover and illuminate what is culturally distinctive about the ways in which nanotechnology is talked about within a particular segment of the scientific community, that is, scientists and engineers who self-identify as working in nanotechnology. For the researcher embarking on an investigation of a culture that is not his or her own, a cultural codes approach to communicative conduct is useful in obtaining even a rudimentary understanding of the cultural worlds of the community being investigated. The social and ethical implications of nanoscience and nanotechnologies afford one area where an examination of scientific discourse may provide both “descriptive” and “theoretic” value, two goals of ethnographies of communication (Philipsen & Coutu, 2005, p. 357). An examination of the discourses surrounding NSE would provide descriptive value in identifying the speech codes within a particular scientific “communal conversation” (Philipsen, 2002). Additionally, such analysis has the theoretical value of suggesting how to understand, engage in, challenge, or otherwise appropriate the discourse (Philipsen, 1997). This research also has the theoretic value of adding to the cumulative extant literature on sociolinguistics and science and technology studies.

sec.title: Research Questions
sec.p: With the above descriptive and theoretic goals in mind, the overarching research question guiding this study asks what communal conversation is taking place about the values of technology and science in general, and about nanotechnologies in particular, within the scientific community. This purpose is expressed by the following three research questions:

list-item.p: Research Question 1: How do these scientists and engineers working at the nanoscale talk about their research?
Research Question 2: How do these scientists and engineers working at the nanoscale talk about social and ethical implications of NSE?
Research Question 3: What speech code (or codes) are evident in the communal conversation about NSE among these scientists and engineers?

sec.title: Method
sec.p: My interest in the discourse of nanotechnology stems from a broader interest in how communication both creates culture and is itself created by culture (see Philipsen, 1987). Specifically, I am interested in how the discourse around nanotechnology creates or contributes to the maintenance of a scientific culture and how this culture enables or constrains the discourse that represents it. Thus, in order to examine the relationship between scientific discourse and scientific culture, I turned to an ethnographic approach to interrogate this relationship. Although ethnographies have become common modes of social science research in science and technology studies (Hess, 2001), to my knowledge, an ethnography of communication has not previously been conducted in a scientific setting. Because my research interest was specifically focused on communication about nanotechnology, I chose to use this methodological and theoretical approach.

My goal in conducting this research was to understand the cultural aspects of the discourse of nanoscience/nanotechnologies through a comparison of observed behavior and actual speech. To achieve this goal, I used multiple modes of inquiry, including fieldwork, participant observation, and interviews based on a method advocated by Briggs (1986) described below. This methodological approach is consistent with published ethnographies of communication (see, e.g., Katriel & Philipsen, 1981) as well as general ethnographies conducted in the field of science and technology studies (see, e.g., Hess, 2001).

Data analyzed for this study were obtained from two main sets of materials. The first set of materials I collected was based on my fieldnotes from 4 years of experiences in nanoscience classrooms, attending scientific lectures, participating and observing three conferences (one on nanoethics, one on nanotechnology, and one on technology in general), and conducting informal interviews with various stakeholders in these arenas. My second set of materials consists of 20 in-depth interviews I conducted with scientists at the university associated with the Center for Nanotechnology in which they discussed their research and their views of SEI posed by the research. The length of time I spent in the field, triangulation of data sources, and use of standard data collection and analysis methods for similar studies all contributed to the validity of this study. Data saturation was achieved at 20 interviews when I began hearing similar responses from those I interviewed. The respondents interviewed for this study are recognized by their peers to be among the leading researchers in nanoscience and nanotechnology in the United States and represent a wide range of disciplines in science and engineering.

I analyzed the data I collected from the interviews using discourse analysis to identify and explicate participant meanings. Additionally, I considered these responses in light of what I had learned during my field-level activities. Although I consulted the fieldnotes I had made from these activities, I did not conduct a formal analysis of these data, opting instead to use the data set as a background for understanding the interview data and indicating (or supporting) the use of particular speech codes. Utilizing an approach described by Schatzman and Strauss (1973, p. 117), I conducted multiple readings of all my materials, moving back and forth between my fieldnotes, my observational notes, and the interview transcripts to complete my analysis.

I approached the analysis of the interview data in the following way. First, I printed out copies of each transcribed interview and read through each one on its own terms, making notes in the margins and underlining words and phrases that caught my attention. I also began to map out the linear path of the event, noting how the interview began, how it proceeded, how it ended, and whether there were any shifts in key or genre.

Second, I analyzed the individual responses I received to my questions from each interviewee, considering the metacommunicative features of each response and verifying my interpretations by considering the context. I also used Hymes’s (1972) SPEAKING1 framework, a dialectical system in which one or more of the elements of a communicative interaction can be examined in relation to each other. In all, I read each transcript in its entirety a minimum of six times and reviewed those portions I highlighted during these readings numerous more times throughout the analysis and writing up phases of the project findings.

In presenting portions of the transcripts, I have used a convention illustrated in Johnstone’s (2002) text Discourse Analysis. Thus, I number each line of text, allowing the breaks in text to occur at the right margin, and including in italics a reference number to indicate the respondent. The transcription conventions I used are from those presented in Silverman’s (2003) text (see p. 254).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In the analysis that follows I will focus on Proposition 3 of SCT: “A speech code implicates a culturally distinctive psychology, sociology, and rhetoric” (Philipsen et al., 2005, p. 61). Psychology in this use refers to how the speakers describe or imply ideas about what it means to be a certain kind of person in light of communication, for example, a man should hit unruly children, not talk to them (Philipsen, 1975); “an ‘expert’ should speak to the ‘average citizen’ using ‘simple terms’” (Leighter, 2007, p. 201); or a scientist should not talk about ethics, as I discovered. Sociology refers to ideas about the nature of society, the nature of groups in a society, and the nature of the possibilities or preferred forms of sociation. For example, in some Finnish communities, the preferred form of sociation among groups is one in which the communicative conduct that links people to one another is characterized by quiet observation and respectful silence. This particular speech code values a view of society as one in which its members show respect toward each other by not speaking until they “have something socially worthwhile to say” (Carbaugh, 2005, p. 123). Rhetoric refers to ideas within a given speech community about what is appropriate and effective communicative conduct. For example, allowing a close friend to speak on your behalf was considered appropriate and effective within the Teamsterville community that Philipsen (1975) studied. However, this type of communicative conduct was not valued within a mainstream American speech code and, in fact, devalued as Philipsen describes.

Like Leighter (2007) before me, Proposition 3 is the primary proposition of SCT on which I focused my study of scientific ways of speaking about nanotechnology. Specifically, I looked for what was culturally distinctive about the ways in which this speech community understood notions of identity, social relations, and the role of communication. Where Leighter (2007) used the keyword “citizen” to interrogate his materials, I used a more general frame of “talk about nano” (using one of my respondent’s words) to look for distinctive and shared ideas among my respondents and the speech community I studied regarding “the nature of persons, social relations, and the role of communicative conduct in linking persons in social relations” (Philipsen et al., 2005, p. 61).

I considered aspects of the code that indicate what is culturally distinctive in this speech community regarding understandings of human nature (psychology), social relations (sociology), and strategic conduct (rhetoric; Philipsen et al., 2005, p. 61) by attending to key symbols and their meanings, premises, and rules that correspond to each of the three interrelated areas. I attended to three elements in particular from Hymes’s (1972) SPEAKING framework, “participants,” “ends/goals,” and “acts,” to help elucidate these elements.

sec.title: What SCT Means by “Psychology”
sec.p: In what follows, I use the term psychology in a particular way that is consistent with how the term is treated in SCT, as “implicat[ing] a view of what a person is and how persons are constituted” (Philipsen, 1997, p. 138). In other words, “psychology” in the service of SCT refers to “a local code about the nature of persons” (G. Philipsen, personal communication, January 4, 2008). Thus, when I use the term psychology here, I am not talking about how the members of the speech community I investigated think, but their notion of how people think. My aim is to determine what the scientific speech code I discovered says about the nature of persons from the standpoint of those who use this speech code.

I began my fieldwork activities by attending nanotech seminars open to the public at the university, listening intently for some reference to the issues that had been raised in my literature review but hearing nothing apart from rather dry technical descriptions of the given speaker’s research. During these early months in the field I also attended a nanotechnology conference featuring industry and university researchers working in nanotechnology. As I attended each session and the subsequent question and answer sessions, I detected some tension around the term nanotechnology and began to suspect that discussing SEI was not culturally appropriate in this speech community. I had previously detected both these areas as problematic, both the term itself (nanotechnology) and the topic of SEI related to nanotechnology, particularly in an early interview with a senior nanotech faculty member in which he had discussed the likelihood that additional faculty members would identify social and ethical concerns with nanotechnology. The following excerpt was preceded by a question about whether scientists would perceive risks to be associated with research in nanotechnology:

think you’re gonna get people saying that they’re, that they have big
concerns, you know. That they, uh, will undoubtedly tell you that there
should be proper, you know, regulation and it’s gonna be kind of an
evolution to figure out how to set up proper regulatory agencies to keep
track of these things, you know. But the innate fear of, uh, I mean, there’s
no big difference in my mind between nano (7.0) technology and
chemistry all along, you know. It’s just another chemical, you know. (xxx)
everything is another chemical that you have to worry about. It’s no
different when you get devices than microelectronics or biomedical
devices, you know. There’s a certain amount of, uh, regulation to be done
as these things evolve, you know. I don’t see it as being fundamentally,
uh, different anyway. All that stuff (xxx) will ultimately be handled by the
same regulatory things that are already covering—mostly chemical type
